data.assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (France)
data.notes: On 25 June 2024, around 100 municipal employees, notably social workers and child protection workers, gathered outside the Departmental Council in Chalons-en-Champagne (Grand Est) to demand more staff and better working conditions.

data.assoc_actor_1: Government of France (2017-)
data.notes: On 25 June 2024, at the call of the 'Zarbo' association, around 40 people, including Mayor Fabien Verdier (political affiliation not specified) and municipal councilors, gathered in Chateaudun (Centre-Val de Loire) to express their commitment to freedom of speech. The event was part of a nationwide wave of demonstrations against far-right ideology and racism, and in support of an open society. The event took place after the National Rally (RN) came first in the European elections in France and President Emmanuel Macron announced the dissolution of the National Assembly on 9 June 2024, prompting snap legislative elections, raising fears of a government led by the far-right party. The demonstrators also expressed solidarity for the 'New 'Popular Front' (Nouveau Front Populaire) alliance (left-wing) ahead of the upcoming legislative elections.

data.assoc_actor_1: CRIF: Representative Council of French Jewish Institutions; Jewish Group (France); LICRA: International League Against Racism and Antisemitism
data.notes: On 25 June 2024, at the call of CRIF and LICRA, around 1,000 people, including members of the Jewish community and various party representatives, demonstrated in Lyon (Auvergne-Rhone-Alpes) to condemn antisemitism after the rape of a 12-year-old Jewish girl in Courbevoie on 15 June 2024.

data.assoc_actor_1: CRIF: Representative Council of French Jewish Institutions; Government of France (2017-); Jewish Group (France); LE: The Ecologists; PP: Public Square; PS: Socialist Party (France); RE: Renaissance
data.notes: On 25 June 2024, at the call of CRIF and other Jewish organizations, around 2,000 people, including several local elected officials such as Regional President Renaud Muselier (RE) and PP, The Ecologists, and PS affiliates, gathered in Marseille (Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur) to condemn antisemitism after the rape of a 12-year-old Jewish girl in Courbevoie on 15 June 2024.

data.assoc_actor_1: Students (France)
data.notes: On 25 June 2024, around 50 students' parents and students gathered outside the rectorate in Montpellier (Occitanie) to protest against restrictive laws on homeschooling.

data.assoc_actor_1: CFDT: French Democratic Confederation of Labor; CFE-CGC: French Confederation of Management - General Confederation of Executives; CGT: General Confederation of Labor (France); FO: Workers' Force; Labor Group (France)
data.notes: On 25 June 2024, at the call of CGT, FO, CFE-CGC, and CFDT, around 50 Cristal Union employees gathered for a picket line outside their factory in Pithiviers-le-Vieil (Centre-Val de Loire) to demand the payment of bonuses.

data.assoc_actor_1: FFMC: French Federation of Angry Bikers
data.notes: On 25 June 2024, at the call of FFMC, around 60 motorcyclists gathered in Saint-Brieuc (Bretagne) to demonstrate against the introduction of a compulsory technical inspection of powered two-wheelers.

data.assoc_actor_1: CGT: General Confederation of Labor (France); Labor Group (France)
data.notes: On 25 June 2024, at the call of CGT, 32 striking Gima employees gathered for a picket line outside their factory in Beauvais (Hauts-de-France) to protest against pay cuts and a new working schedule that would force some of them to do nightshifts.

data.assoc_actor_1: Health Workers (France); Labor Group (France); SUD: Democratic Unitary Solidarity
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, at the call of SUD, around 60 striking health workers gathered outside the clinic in Arcachon (Nouvelle-Aquitaine) to demand a pay rise.

data.assoc_actor_1: CGT: General Confederation of Labor (France); Labor Group (France)
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, at the call of CGT FAPT, around 30 striking postal workers gathered outside the mail sorting center in Bonchamp-les-Laval (Centre-Val de Loire) to demand the payment of bonuses for the distribution of leaflets for the 2024 snap legislative elections.

data.assoc_actor_1: CGT: General Confederation of Labor (France); Labor Group (France)
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, at the call of CGT, nursery workers gathered outside the Departmental Council in Creteil (Ile-de-France) to demand more staff and better working conditions.

data.assoc_actor_1: LFI: France Rebellious; Students (France)
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, students, including LFI affiliates, gathered outside the Departmental Council in Creteil (Ile-de-France) to protest against the Departmental President's decision to reduce the funding of transport passes for students in need.

On 24 June 2024, people gathered outside the prison in Dijon (Bourgogne-Franche-Comte) to protest against the arrest of 8 leaders of the CCAT pro-independence movement and their subsequent transfer to prisons in mainland France on 22 June, which the protesters considered a colonial practice. They also demonstrated against the constitutional bill project to enlarge the citizen electoral body, opening it up to people who have lived in New Caledonia for at least 10 years. Participants argued the move would go against the interests of the pro-independence movement.

data.assoc_actor_1: CGT: General Confederation of Labor (France); Labor Group (France)
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, at the call of CGT FAPT, 16 striking postal workers gathered outside the mail sorting center in Le Mans (Pays de la Loire) to demand the payment of bonuses for the distribution of leaflets for the 2024 snap legislative elections.

data.assoc_actor_1: LFI: France Rebellious; NPA: New Anticapitalist Party
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, at the call of MKF - Kanak Movement of France (Mouvement Kanak de France) and Kanaky Solidarity (Solidarite Kanak), around 50 people, including LFI and NPA affiliates, gathered outside the Mulhouse prison in Lutterbach (Grand Est) to protest against the arrest of 8 leaders of the pro-independence CCAT movement and their subsequent transfer to prisons in mainland France on 22 June, which the protesters considered a colonial practice. They also demonstrated against the constitutional bill project to enlarge the citizen electoral body, opening it up to people who have lived in New Caledonia for at least 10 years.

data.assoc_actor_1: CGT: General Confederation of Labor (France); Labor Group (France)
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, at the call of CGT, around 100 child protection workers gathered outside the Departmental Council in Nancy (Grand Est) to demand better working conditions and more staff.

data.assoc_actor_1: Teachers (France)
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, teachers and striking education assistants gathered for a picket line outside the Bernard-de-Ventadour school in Privas (Occitanie) to demand a permanent work contract for one of their colleagues.

On 24 June 2024, around 100 people gathered outside the town hall in Saint-Etienne (Auvergne-Rhone-Alpes) to call for the resignation of Mayor Gael Perdriau, who stood accused of embezzlement and blackmailing at the time of reporting.

data.assoc_actor_1: FO: Workers' Force; Labor Group (France)
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, at the call of FO, around 100 elderly home (EHPAD) workers demonstrated in Saint-Florent-sur-Cher (Centre-Val de Loire) to protest against mismanagement and demand better working conditions.

data.assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (France)
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, 15 fairground workers gathered in Strasbourg (Grand Est) to call for the holding of the Saint-Jean fair despite its previous cancellation.

data.assoc_actor_1: Anarchist Group (France); LFI: France Rebellious
data.notes: On 24 June 2024, around 20 people, including LFI affiliates and anarchist activists, gathered for a spontaneous protest action outside the Victor-Hugo cafe, where an RN meet-up was organized, in Valence (Auvergne-Rhone-Alpes). The event was part of a nationwide wave of demonstrations against far-right ideology and racism, and in support of an open society. The event took place after the National Rally (RN) came first in the European elections in France and President Emmanuel Macron announced the dissolution of the National Assembly on 9 June 2024, prompting snap legislative elections, raising fears of a government led by the far-right party. The demonstrators also expressed solidarity for the 'New 'Popular Front' (Nouveau Front Populaire) alliance (left-wing) ahead of the upcoming legislative elections.

On 24 June 2024, people gathered outside the prison in Villefranche-sur-Saone (Auvergne-Rhone-Alpes) to protest against the arrest of 8 leaders of the CCAT pro-independence movement and their subsequent transfer to prisons in mainland France on 22 June, which the protesters considered a colonial practice. They also demonstrated against the constitutional bill project to enlarge the citizen electoral body, opening it up to people who have lived in New Caledonia for at least 10 years. Participants argued the move would go against the interests of the pro-independence movement.

data.assoc_actor_1: CRIF: Representative Council of French Jewish Institutions; Government of France (2017-); Jewish Group (France); Muslim Group (France); UDI: Union of Democrats and Independents
data.notes: On 23 June 2024, at the call of CRIF, several hundred people, including Mayor Sophie Joissains (UDI), as well as members of the Jewish and Muslim communities, demonstrated in Aix-en-Provence (Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur) to condemn antisemitism after the rape of a 12-year-old Jewish girl in Courbevoie on 15 June 2024.

data.assoc_actor_1: CFDT: French Democratic Confederation of Labor; CGT: General Confederation of Labor (France); FSU: United Federation of Trade Unions; Labor Group (France); MFPF: French Movement for Family Planning; NT: Nous Toutes; Oxfam; SUD: Democratic Unitary Solidarity; UNSA: National Union of Autonomous Trade Unions; Women (France)
data.notes: On 23 June 2024, at the call of Women in Solidarity (Femmes Solidaires), people demonstrated in Bastia (Corse). The event was part of a nationwide wave of demonstrations called by CFDT, CGT, UNSA, SUD, and FSU, as well as more than 200 feminist organizations such as MFPF, NT, and Oxfam, condemning far-right ideology, which the demonstrators deemed dangerous to women's rights. The event took place after the National Rally (RN) came first in the European elections in France and President Emmanuel Macron announced the dissolution of the National Assembly on 9 June 2024, prompting snap legislative elections, raising fears of a government led by the far-right party.

data.assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (France); LGBTQ+ (France); SUD: Democratic Unitary Solidarity
data.notes: On 23 June 2024, at the call of SUD, several hundred people, including members of the LGBTQ+ community, demonstrated in Montpellier (Occitanie) to condemn far-right ideology after a member of the LGBTQ+ community and a union member were beaten up by far-right activists during the 'Festival des Fanfares' fair on 1 June 2024.

On 23 June 2024, around 50 people biked through the city and slowed down traffic in Montpellier (Occitanie), as part of a so-called 'Velorution', to protest against the construction of a bypass road around the city, which they deemed damaging to the environment, citing additional congestion.

On 23 June 2024, at the call of the environmental group Less Beton (Less Concrete), around 20 people gathered in Mur-de-Bretagne (Bretagne) to protest against the enlargement of the RN164 road, which they deemed damaging to local biodiversity.

data.notes: On 23 June 2024, 75,000 people, including students, CFDT Secretay General Marylise Leon, CGT Secretary General Sophie Binet (CGT), and SNES-FSU Secretary General Sophie Venetitay (SNES-FSU), marched from Republique to Nation in Paris (Ile-de-France). The event was part of a nationwide wave of demonstrations called by CFDT, CGT, UNSA, SUD, and FSU, as well as more than 200 feminist organizations such as MFPF, NT, and Oxfam, condemning far-right ideology, which the demonstrators deemed dangerous to women's rights. The event took place after the National Rally (RN) came first in the European elections in France and President Emmanuel Macron announced the dissolution of the National Assembly on 9 June 2024, prompting snap legislative elections, raising fears of a government led by the far-right party.

data.assoc_actor_1: Catholic Christian Group (France); La Cimade
data.notes: On 23 June 2024, at the call of CCFD-Terre Solidaire - Catholic Committee against Hunger and for Development, Anastasis, La Cimade, Struggle and Contemplation (Lutte et Contemplation) and other organizations, more than 200 members of the Catholic community gathered outside of the Invalides in Paris (Ile-de-France) to oppose the National Rally, citing their the party's values were 'incompatible' with Christian ones. The event took place after the National Rally (RN) came first in the European elections in France and President Emmanuel Macron announced the dissolution of the National Assembly on 9 June 2024, prompting snap legislative elections, raising fears of a government led by the far-right party.

On 23 June 2024, at the call of Kanaky Solidarity (Solidarite Kanaky) and AISDPK - Association for Information and Support for the Rights of the Kanak People (Association Information et Soutien aux Droits du Peuple Kanak), a small crowd gathered outside the Ministry of Justice in Paris (Ile-de-France) to protest against the arrest of 8 leaders of the CCAT pro-independence movement and their subsequent transfer to prisons in mainland France on 22 June, which the protesters considered a colonial practice. They also demonstrated against the constitutional bill project to enlarge the citizen electoral body, opening it up to people who have lived in New Caledonia for at least 10 years. Participants argued the move would go against the interests of the pro-independence movement.

data.assoc_actor_1: CFDT: French Democratic Confederation of Labor; CGT: General Confederation of Labor (France); FSU: United Federation of Trade Unions; Labor Group (France); MFPF: French Movement for Family Planning; NT: Nous Toutes; Oxfam; SUD: Democratic Unitary Solidarity; UNSA: National Union of Autonomous Trade Unions; Women (France)
data.notes: On 23 June 2024, several hundred people demonstrated in Poitiers (Nouvelle-Aquitaine). The event was part of a nationwide wave of demonstrations called by CFDT, CGT, UNSA, SUD, and FSU, as well as more than 200 feminist organizations such as MFPF, NT, and Oxfam, condemning far-right ideology, which the demonstrators deemed dangerous to women's rights. The event took place after the National Rally (RN) came first in the European elections in France and President Emmanuel Macron announced the dissolution of the National Assembly on 9 June 2024, prompting snap legislative elections, raising fears of a government led by the far-right party.
